title: Is Gender Inequality worsening in India?
text:
“The World Economic Forum (WEF) ranked India at 135 out of 146 countries in the Global Gender Gap Index in the report’s 2022 edition.” — WEF Report


This data story seeks to analyse how gender inequality in India has changed over time by answering the following questions:

How has labor force participation rate (LFPR) of males and females changed over time in India?
What is the proportion of females in India’s labor force?
What proportion of youth in India are not in Education, Employment or Training?
How do education levels differ for males and females in India?

title: About
text:
I am Jaren Ong, year 3 business administration student. I find joy in learning and seeking growth. I am proud to have learnt a new skill in R and to apply it in my own capacity. I am grateful for Prof NV’s work, as well as the good work of Naman and Yitian.
link to my GitHub: https://github.com/deludedjaren/Jaren

title: Final Write-up
text:
What is the topic that you have finalized?
This project aims to assess gender inequality in India by comparing female and male labor force participation rates and education levels, shedding light on disparities in economic and educational opportunities.


What are the data sources that you have curated so far?
I have attached the data set I curated in the csv file below.

title: W12 Submission
text:
Week 10

What is the question that you are going to answer? (Answer: One sentence that ends with a question mark that could act like the title of your data story),
Is gender equality getting worse in India?


Why is this an important question? (Answer: 3 sentences, each of which has some evidence, e.g., “According to the United Nations…” to justify why the question you have chosen is important),
The question of whether gender equality is getting worse in India is significant due to several compelling reasons. According to the United Nations’ Human Development Index, India’s Gender Inequality Index (GII) ranks it as one of the countries with persistent gender disparities. India’s GII, according to the 2020 Human Development Report, stood at 0.501, indicating substantial gender inequality. Furthermore, evidence from the National Family Health Survey-4 (NFHS-4) shows that despite improvements in some areas, India still grapples with gender-based issues like maternal mortality, child marriage, and violence against women, underscoring the need to assess whether the situation is improving or deteriorating. Lastly, tracking changes in gender equality in India is vital as it can inform policy and program development to address disparities and promote a more inclusive and equitable society.


Which rows and columns of the dataset will be used to answer this question? (Answer: Actual names of the variables in the dataset that you plan to use).
I currently intend to utilize all my variables to create a story on how gender inequality is evolving in India.

title: W12 Submission
text:
Week 11

1. List the visualizations that you are going to use in your project (Answer: What are the variables that you are going to plot? How will it answer your larger question?),
The main variables that I will likely focus on will be labor force participation rate for females and males.


2. How do you plan to make it interactive? (Answer: features of ggplot2/shiny/markdown do you plan to use to make the story interactive) ,
Try to use Shiny, although I am not very sure how to do so.


3. What concepts incorporated in your project were taught in the course and which ones were self-learnt? (Answer: Create a table with topics in one column and Weeks in the other to indicate which concept taught in which week is being used. Leave the entry of the Week column empty for self-learnt concepts)
I will update this as my website develops


Include the challenges and errors that you faced and how you overcame them.
I struggle to incorporate Shiny into my website.

Week 12

title: Final Submission
text:
This project aims to assess gender inequality in India by analysing labor and educational statistics over time.



I collected secondary data from the CEIC website, which is a website which compiles data sources from a myriad of reliable data sources such as the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, data.gov.in and more.

title: Final Submission
text:
This project aims to assess gender inequality in India by analysing labor and educational statistics over time.



I collected secondary data from the CEIC website, which is a website which compiles data sources from a myriad of reliable data sources such as the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, data.gov.in and more.

title: Final Submission
text:
Week 10

What is the question that you are going to answer? (Answer: One sentence that ends with a question mark that could act like the title of your data story),
Is gender equality getting worse in India?


Why is this an important question? (Answer: 3 sentences, each of which has some evidence, e.g., “According to the United Nations…” to justify why the question you have chosen is important),
The question of whether gender equality is getting worse in India is significant due to several compelling reasons. According to the United Nations’ Human Development Index, India’s Gender Inequality Index (GII) ranks it as one of the countries with persistent gender disparities. India’s GII, according to the 2020 Human Development Report, stood at 0.501, indicating substantial gender inequality. Furthermore, evidence from the National Family Health Survey-4 (NFHS-4) shows that despite improvements in some areas, India still grapples with gender-based issues like maternal mortality, child marriage, and violence against women, underscoring the need to assess whether the situation is improving or deteriorating. Lastly, tracking changes in gender equality in India is vital as it can inform policy and program development to address disparities and promote a more inclusive and equitable society.


Which rows and columns of the dataset will be used to answer this question? (Answer: Actual names of the variables in the dataset that you plan to use).
I will use “Female.LFPR”, “Male.LFPR”, “Labour.Force..Female….of.Total.Labour.Force”, “MaleYouthNotInEET” and “FemaleYouthNotInEET”.

title: Final Submission
text:
Week 11

1. List the visualizations that you are going to use in your project (Answer: What are the variables that you are going to plot? How will it answer your larger question?),
I am going to plot Male LFPR and Female LFPR against Time to show: (1) the stark difference between male and female LFPR and (2) how LFPR for both genders have changed over time in order to answer the question of whether or not gender inequality is worsening in terms of occupational and economic opportunities.
Next, I will plot the graph for proportion of females in labor force to show how female workers remain the minority over time in India, which can either be an indicator or cause of gender discrimination in India.
Lastly, I will plot the difference in educational levels between males and female workers to see how males have unfair access to education when compared to their female counterparts.


2. How do you plan to make it interactive? (Answer: features of ggplot2/shiny/markdown do you plan to use to make the story interactive) ,
I will focus on using ggplot2 to create meaningful visualizations which can walk the user through the issue of gender inequality in India. I have made the decision not to incorporate shiny into my webpage as I feel that the plots generated are sufficient in answering the question of whether or not gender inequality is worsening in India.


3. What concepts incorporated in your project were taught in the course and which ones were self-learnt? (Answer: Create a table with topics in one column and Weeks in the other to indicate which concept taught in which week is being used. Leave the entry of the Week column empty for self-learnt concepts)







Week
Concept Used + How It Was Used




1
How to use Rstudio + Using Rmarkdown


2
Data visualization and use of ggplot2


4
Tidying my data to ensure that it works in ggplot2


7
Creating meaningful visualizations. I mainly used geom_line to show change over time.





Include the challenges and errors that you faced and how you overcame them.
I attempted to incorporate shiny into my webpage but was not successful. I managed to run the app in Rstudio but could not get it to work when I published it. After thorough consideration, I decided to move on without the use of shiny as I felt that it did not add significant value to my story.

title: Final Submission
text:
Week 12

Include the challenges and errors that you faced and how you overcame them.
Over W12, I attempted to plot ggplot2 graphs but struggled to do so for some variables due to the presence of NA values. I was not confident in tidying data in R before plotting it out. I sought help from Prof NV which allowed me to make progress as I was able to plot the graphs I wanted to answer the questions I had in mind.
That being said, given that this is the first time I am creating a website, I remained unsure on how to design it in a way that looks aesthetic. I also struggled to come up with a coherent story which conveyed the main issue that my website is trying to address. I am still in the process of coming up with questions which would allow me to answer the issue of how gender inequality has evolved over time in India.

title: Final Submission
text:

4. What are the insights from the data and how are they depicted in plots?


5. How did you implement this entire project? Were there any new concepts that you learnt to implement some aspects of it?

title: Gender Inequality in India
section: Male vs Female Youth Exclusion from Education, Employment or Training
text: Male vs Female Youth Exclusion from Education, Employment or Training

title: Gender Inequality in India
section: Male vs Female Workers Education Level
text:
Male vs Female Workers Education Level






Analysis of Gender Inequality in India
It can be seen from these visualization that there is evidence of gender inequality in India. The data shows that males have an unfair advantage in educational and economic opportunities. Next, we will be analysing whether or not gender inequality is worsening over time.

title: Is Gender Inequality worsening?
section: Gender Proportions in India’s Labor Force Over Time
text: Gender Proportions in India’s Labor Force Over Time

title: Is Gender Inequality worsening?
section: Youth exclusion from Education, Employment or Training over time
text: Youth exclusion from Education, Employment or Training over time

title: Is Gender Inequality worsening?
section: Difference between Male and Female education levels over time
text:
Difference between Male and Female education levels over time






Has Gender Inequality worsened?
Through analysis of data from 1990 to 2022, I cannot conclude that gender inequality has worsened over time. Whilst gender inequality remains an issue for India, the above data shows that the economic gap between males and females is reducing as the gap between female LFPR and male LFPR has generally reduced over time. Furthermore, a much larger proportion of female youths now have access to education, employment or training, with the gender gap decreasing from 43% in 1990 to 29% in 2022. Lastly, The average education level of the female worker has seen growth against the average male worker. The educational gap between males and females has decreased from 56% in 2000 to less than 50% in 2022. Whilst gender inequality has improved over time, the improvement can be considered to be minimal, with the gender gap still being very wide, as seen in the recent WEF report which ranked India at 135 out of 146 countries in the Global Gender Gap Index.
